replies.body: Is it okay if we mix and match skin series that aren't stated to be related in the League lore? (for example, writing a story combining aspects of the Arcade series skins and Mafia)

This would be the key here:

>As long as your entry features one or more League of Legends characters and is recognisably set in one of the alternate worlds of our skins, you're right to write.

To me there's nothing there preventing you from doing what would essentially be a crossover universe, so long as both themes are clear and have a purpose. Of course crossovers are harder, because you have to nail the feel and characters of both worlds, but if done well that might even win you some extra points. I'm sure Achenar will clarify sometime soon if they aren't looking for crossovers.

Sera's Dragon is too good, too fast, and absolutely on the money!

Crossovers between universes are perfectly fine and welcome. :D

Sorry, could someone please explain what '_and feature one of our skin lines in some way_' means? Thank you! =]

It just means that the story has to involve one of the skin lines from the game, such as the High Noon, Mafia or Cosmic skin lines, for example. The basic concept is that each skin line represents an alternate reality or timeline from the "standard" lore of LoL.

If you want a good way to take a look at the various skin lines in-game, you can go to the Skins tab of the Collection in the client, and change the sorting option to "Set" (Will probably be on "My Collection" by default).

Hey, so I have created a work, and it's 1515 words long. Will this breach the rules? It's one of those moments when you really like what you've done and really don't want to change it, but if it won't be accepted then I'll have to cut something.
Also...If I have a sentence or two as description of the lore/brief explanation of whats happening, does that count towards the word cap?

When I did essays all the time at school there was a 5% allowance, but given the nature of the contest I'm gonna say keep it strictly to the 1500 unless Achenar says otherwise.

A narration style intro would fall into that 1500 imo. A simple statement of what world you're using wouldn't, but should also be apparent from the story itself and therefore unnecessary.

If you're really struggling, have a friend read over it and see if any words stand out to them as unnecessary or overused. If you're using more than one or two adjectives to describe something, try cutting the least useful ones. Concision has value as much as immersive description, it's a matter of how they are used.

Sometimes a fresh set of eyes is all you need :)

So, looking at the Wiki, each themed skin has a brief description of what each champ did/does, do we have to incorporate these into the story? Or can we do something different? For example, Dragon Sorceress Zyra is the baddie according to its description, could we make her a goodie in the story?
Also another example in Dragonslayer world, Pantheons story says he was the last of the dragon slayers, so like, how can they all fit together

So Pantheon is listed as "the last of the *ancient* dragonslayers", the implication being that Pantheon has lived a really long time, and all the other Dragonslayers are essentially the new generation that rose up when dragons returned. This is further backed up backed up by Braum's snippet:

>most of the ancient warriors had passed away, leaving Braum to take up to their task

Regarding Zyra, the lore indicates she is essentially the source of the dragons returning, and they certainly aren't playing nice. 

There's nothing stating you have to stick to the established lore, but deviating without a compelling reason will likely only hurt you. Consider that the best characters are those that have real reasons for doing what they do - the ones that make sense, not the ones that are just "I'm evil/good because I am", and this is especially true for villains.

On the other hand, everyone loves a good redemption story :)

Hey! Unfortunately this contest is limited to Oceanic players. However if you'd like to write a piece and share it with the community, go for it - we'd love to see your work!
Is using a single-line skin such as the Firefang Warwick skin allowed, or does it have to be a skin line?

Short answer yes!

The contest is about the alternate universe, and those universes exist for every skin, it's just a matter of how fleshed out it is.

Though it wouldn't be unusual to put Firefang into the Infernal universe I would think, though I don't believe they are officially related.

Can we write about a champion in a universe where they do not yet have a skin? For example, Star Guardian Diana or Arclight Zed?

Does the fanfiction have to somehow correlate to the short bios of the skins?

Hey! Ultimately it doesn't need to be a perfect match, if a bit of a change will improve your story - but should still be recognisable as belonging to that universe. So for example, changing the fact that Star Guardian Ahri has lost team members in the past is potentially fine, if it makes sense for the story (eg. it's set before that happens, or maybe it didn't happen at all and it's just how Ahri thinks of a particular event) - changing the universe to the point that she's actually a mecha pilot is probably a bit more of a stretch. ;)

Sorry HeartVine! There's a lot to go through come entry judging time and we need to make sure we can get through them all. A few hundred words may not seem like much, but it adds up big time down the track! There's a lot to be said about concise writing, which is said better using few words. As Dr. Seuss once wrote:  “The writer who breeds more words than he needs, is making a chore for the reader who reads.”

Personally I'm a fan of the more concise stories, ones that drag on kind of lose their magic in my eyes.

In doing it this way the nature of the stories people write will gravitate toward being concise (the perfect word for it)
and more dense in their detail and readability, methinks this limit'll shape this into a pretty competitive little shindig,
